title: Matplotlib Introduction
text:
Learn how to use Pixi to create, manage, and reproduce a Python environment using only Pixiâ€™s core features.




How to install and verify Pixi
How to create a new environment
How to install packages from conda-forge and PyPI
How to activate the environment and run commands
How to export and share the environment




Visit pixi.sh and follow the instructions for your operating system.
Example for Windows:
winget install prefix-dev.pixi
Verify installation:
pixi --version



Create a new project directory:
mkdir my-data-env
cd my-data-env
pixi init
This creates a pixi.toml file where your environment is defined.



pixi add python pip
Verify Python is available:
pixi shell
python --version
pip --version
Type exit to leave the shell.



Install useful packages:
pixi add pandas matplotlib
Install a PyPI-only package (such as tabulate):
pixi add --pypi tabulate
View environment info:
pixi info



Create a file test.py:
import pandas as pd
from tabulate import tabulate

df = pd.DataFrame({'A': [1, 2], 'B': [3, 4]})
print(tabulate(df, headers='keys', tablefmt='pretty'))
Run it inside the environment:
pixi run python test.py



To share: - Send pixi.toml and pixi.lock
To reproduce on another machine:
pixi install
pixi run python test.py



You have now:

Created a Pixi-managed environment
Installed packages from both conda and PyPI
Used pixi run and pixi shell
Reproduced the environment with lock files

title: Matplotlib Introduction
text:
Set up a reproducible Python environment using Pixi and share it with others via pixi.toml and pixi.lock.




Go to the official Pixi installation page.
On Windows, run:

winget install prefix-dev.pixi

Verify installation:

pixi --version



pixi init
This command creates a pixi.toml file in the current directory.



pixi add python pip
This installs Python and pip from the conda-forge ecosystem.



pixi shell
You are now inside the managed environment.



Example:
pixi add numpy matplotlib
Or from PyPI:
pixi add --pypi streamlit




Commit or send the pixi.toml and pixi.lock files.
Others can recreate the same environment by running:

pixi install



You have successfully created and shared a Python environment using Pixi.

title: Pandas Introduction
text:
Pandas Introduction
Pandas is a Python library for handling tabular data.
import pandas as pd

data = {'Name': ['Alice', 'Bob'], 'Age': [25, 30]}
df = pd.DataFrame(data)
print(df)

title: Matplotlib Introduction
text:
Matplotlib Basics
Simple plots in Matplotlib:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.plot([1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6])
plt.show()

title: NumPy Introduction
text:
NumPy Introduction
NumPy is the foundation for numerical computing in Python.
import numpy as np

arr = np.array([1, 2, 3, 4])
print(arr)
